Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Vianair Airspace Information Model For Airspace Design And Planning
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will result from improving the efficiency of air traffic operations and unlocking runway and airspace capacity utilization, thus enabling reduction of emissions, noise impact, flight delays, and operational cost of airports and airlines. As urban metropolitan areas have grown and air traffic has increased, capacity constraints at airports and their surrounding airspace result in daily delays, which propagate throughout the entire National Airspace System affecting almost every person in modern society with negative impact on the economy, the environment, and airport neighboring communities. The proposed innovation will enable airport authorities, airlines and air navigation service providers in the US and worldwide to more efficiently plan, design and manage airspace and airports systems, facilitating the seamless sharing of information between stakeholders, ultimately enabling the transition of the air traffic management system into the future and resulting in significant benefits for the traveling public and the local communities.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop the first-of-its-kind Airspace Information Model (AIM), a dedicated software platform for airspace and airport system planning and design. Currently, airport authorities, airlines and the air navigation service providers use a plethora of tools for airspace and airport system design, planning and performance evaluation. However, existing tools only cater for specific aspects of the operation in isolation and fail to properly evaluate the interactions between system design components and the trade-offs between different performance objectives. As a result, system performance is sub-optimal. The proposed AIM platform combines the functions of Design, Performance Evaluation and Optimization in a single parametric model addressing the airspace design and planning process from a holistic perspective. It also makes an immediate evaluation of all performance trade-offs possible, while accounting for design rules and criteria. Furthermore, this SBIR proposes the development and integration into the AIM platform of the Dynamic Route Concept (DRC), a novel airspace design optimization method that automatically matches airspace design configuration to dynamic air traffic demand, thus enabling pre-tactical decision-making and optimal system performance. The proposed technology has the potential to become the industry-wide standard.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project proposed the development of Vianair AIM, the next generation airport and airspace design, management and performance evaluation platform for the efficient design & evaluation of airspace procedures and performance assessment of airport operations.

Airports and airlines - our target customers - perform various tasks related to: 1) Airspace procedure design (the design of departure and arrival flight routes) to improve their operational efficiency, and; 2) Evaluating airspace and airport operations. Today, legacy software systems that address the above tasks are outdated and difficult to use, presenting technical limitations and only providing piecemeal solutions. This status-quo reduces the efficiency of airports and airlines, while resulting in excess air traffic congestion & delays, fuel burn, operational cost, noise and emissions and reduced system capacity.

Vianair introduces a novel Airspace Information Modeling (AIM) concept that unifies, in a single platform, design and evaluation capabilities, while providing real-time feedback to the user during design time. The anticipated result is for Vianair AIM to enable airports/airlines to be far more efficient and be able to resume pre-pandemic air traffic operations, while also balancing operational, societal and environmental objectives.

In Phase I, we conducted initial Research and Development (R&D) on the AIM concept and developed the specifications to support basic airspace design and safety evaluation capabilities, and performance evaluation in terms of key metrics such as fuel burn, travel time and noise impact. In parallel, we researched various software architectures to blend together the above prototype tools in a single unified platform and developed an initial implementation of an innovative Model-View-View Model (MVVM) software architecture that can support real-time feedback of design objective trade-offs - validating the technical feasibility of the AIM concept. Subsequently, we developed an initial Minimum Viable Product (MVP) prototype of the Vianair AIM, incorporating the above-mentioned early prototype tools.

In parallel to our R&D activities, we conducted market validation activities with target customers. In January 2020, we initiated a trial contract with one of the four busiest airports in Europe. In June 2020, we started a trial with one of the four largest US airlines. And in June 2020, we signed a paid contract with a major US airport authority for licensing a Vianair AIM prototype. These initial customers engagements helped us identify a key customer base and validate our target customers? willingness to purchase our solution. At the end of Phase I, we continued the development of the Vianair AIM software platform using feedback from our target customers via our ongoing engagements to inform our R&D. Following Phase I, we plan to continue our R&D to complete the development of the Vianair AIM product and successfully commercialize our technology to reduce air travel delays, improve safety of operations and reduce monetary and environmental costs incurred by air traffic and airport operations.

Vianair addresses a problem that affects almost every person in our society: the impact of flight delays on the Economy, the Environment and our Communities. Vianair?s technology improves efficiency of air traffic operations and unlocks runway and airspace capacity utilization, thus enabling economic growth, while also reducing emissions, noise impact, flight delays, and operational costs. Preliminary development and testing of Vianair?s technology for the NY airport system indicate the potential to increase airport runway capacity and airspace utilization by as much as 20%, while savings for delays, fuel burn, noise impact and controller workload ranged between 10% and 21%, corresponding to potential cost savings of $2bn/year in the NY-area operations alone. Vianair AIM has the potential to become industry standard and be used by 150 airports and 40 airlines globally, addressing a served available market of over $100M. Leadership in the modernization of air navigation helps ensure that the US retains its role as the world leader in aviation. Lastly, Vianair employs state-of-the-art methods and technologies that enable the development of new airspace infrastructure incorporating the latest available technological and conceptual advancements, and in turn, the integration of new technologies (e.g. drones, next generation satellite navigation systems) and automation in the current air traffic management system, enabling the transition of the latter into the future.
